description: From Middle English constreinen, from Old French constreindre, from Latin cōnstringō, from cōn- (“with, together”) +‎ stringō (“to draw, bind or tie tight”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *streyg- (“to stroke, to shear, stiff”).

verbs.description: constrain (third-person singular simple present constrains, present participle constraining, simple past and past participle constrained)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To force physically, by strong persuasion or pressuring; to compel; to oblige.
(transitive) To keep within close bounds; to confine.
(transitive) To reduce a result in response to limited resources.
